Expectation1: Deliver packages on time and to the correct address
Situation1: A medical supply delivery must reach a hospital department on schedule to ensure patient care
Expectation2: Participate in community rituals and ceremonies
Situation2: A community memorial service at the temple takes place tonight with many attendees expected.
Story:
I glanced at the clock on my dashboard, my hands gripping the steering wheel tighter than usual. The hospital’s address blinked on my delivery app, a reminder that the medical supplies in my trunk were urgently needed. I could almost feel the weight of the patients’ hopes, the nurses’ anxious glances at the clock, all depending on me to arrive on time. My supervisor’s words echoed in my mind: “No delays, especially not for the hospital runs.”

But tonight was also the memorial service at the temple. The community would gather, incense curling in the air, chanting for those who had passed. As a Buddhist, I was expected to be there, to help set up, to join in the prayers, to show compassion and presence. My teacher had asked me personally, “Will you help us tonight?” I could picture the faces of the elders, the gentle nods of gratitude.

Caught between the urgency of my delivery and the pull of my spiritual community, my chest tightened. I wanted to be reliable in both worlds, but the roads ahead seemed to split, each demanding all of me. I sat in my car, the engine idling, torn and uncertain.
